The red curves show the critical curves for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{S}\\, =0.764$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"132874617\" scrollto-destination=\"132874617\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=rKACI9RHpTkXlZU54NSP1EiI1bxjBuhERq6BHZSslgmTnGfI8C9fqi2fqS48hiWaT0jN0ho~kfExQCkavBtsoJpOKhY8DoLJdXL8MvPq4ivPJD-Bph25FIcxyrtjePhz0e4I1rG-kN91LULq8riI4qrWaojmGnQ6rCikwtt4~36K7UI3kh6HUxVk8nUNDNra74lw8oaLfrJX7pnd0A6APsAKVfsiMkwQM~LpuqLRjxqfqvHOsg7pPut4rr40JY1FRJ~HZ4C0qXqtnbrTLYg4W13kQKnl1HPWBmOWTa5MbfLsvt9tLtSCdEToCCReyown0ytQy4EQ33P-Xog0z6Fjcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Central region of SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401, centred on the BCG. Examples from our data are shown as follows: GMOS i-band observation (left); GMOS-based difference image (right). The red curve is the tangential critical curve for $z_\\mathrm{S}\\, =1.963$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874617/stz675fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874617\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=TgVHS-G9psDERQuSah4~TmO2-d04GMpKic6m2ZYScdT4oyASrGchdDJ~8K2848i3UWv~ntov08zCQ-NNq1BF7xW-6G~ft0niIEkCy3yo5xM6OkfonTzeIM9xDGGfha9o11Dqm3bLHqlQgfkSuVeZSomhmxB5yVHLJ3e3ZVnXrHqCLZcZ-Zus2TtCUenZM3aCpi3TB0F5g7MphNLHKZL4KxvymUgrJBWIXF4Ak5eVRb3SKPNSol2uY82VfZGZBr3HFDJ81psFkfXHNUm5lfVp2wH5f67CWyMCkChlD5P~-2LiWiwYwDHahM4bw2JQeTLFeM6Q6yTB4nbnxidER8AdJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874617&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central region of SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401, centred on the BCG. Examples from our data are shown as follows: GMOS <em>i</em>-band observation (left); GMOS-based difference image (right). The red curve is the tangential critical curve for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{S}\\, =1.963$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a04.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=rKACI9RHpTkXlZU54NSP1EiI1bxjBuhERq6BHZSslgmTnGfI8C9fqi2fqS48hiWaT0jN0ho~kfExQCkavBtsoJpOKhY8DoLJdXL8MvPq4ivPJD-Bph25FIcxyrtjePhz0e4I1rG-kN91LULq8riI4qrWaojmGnQ6rCikwtt4~36K7UI3kh6HUxVk8nUNDNra74lw8oaLfrJX7pnd0A6APsAKVfsiMkwQM~LpuqLRjxqfqvHOsg7pPut4rr40JY1FRJ~HZ4C0qXqtnbrTLYg4W13kQKnl1HPWBmOWTa5MbfLsvt9tLtSCdEToCCReyown0ytQy4EQ33P-Xog0z6Fjcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Central region of SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401, centred on the BCG. Examples from our data are shown as follows: GMOS i-band observation (left); GMOS-based difference image (right). The red curve is the tangential critical curve for $z_\\mathrm{S}\\, =1.963$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874617/stz675fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874617\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=TgVHS-G9psDERQuSah4~TmO2-d04GMpKic6m2ZYScdT4oyASrGchdDJ~8K2848i3UWv~ntov08zCQ-NNq1BF7xW-6G~ft0niIEkCy3yo5xM6OkfonTzeIM9xDGGfha9o11Dqm3bLHqlQgfkSuVeZSomhmxB5yVHLJ3e3ZVnXrHqCLZcZ-Zus2TtCUenZM3aCpi3TB0F5g7MphNLHKZL4KxvymUgrJBWIXF4Ak5eVRb3SKPNSol2uY82VfZGZBr3HFDJ81psFkfXHNUm5lfVp2wH5f67CWyMCkChlD5P~-2LiWiwYwDHahM4bw2JQeTLFeM6Q6yTB4nbnxidER8AdJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874617&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central region of SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401, centred on the BCG. Examples from our data are shown as follows: GMOS <em>i</em>-band observation (left); GMOS-based difference image (right). The red curve is the tangential critical curve for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{S}\\, =1.963$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The wavelength range of the MUSE datacube (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$475\\,\\,\\lt\\,\\, \\lambda\\,\\, \\lt\\,\\, 930\\, {\\rm nm}$|\u2060</span>) obtained from our observations of Abell 3084 enables great freedom in the choice of reference image when constructing a difference image. We selected the <em>HST</em>/ACS observation through the F606W filter (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>) as the reference image. We therefore created a F606W pseudo-image from the MUSE datacube for each night upon which we observed Abell 3084, by multiplying the datacubes with the transmission curve of the F606W filter, and integrating under the transmission curve. The difference images were then produced by minimizing residuals in all detected sources, following a similar procedure described by Bacon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in the MUSE observations of the Ultra Deep Field. This optimization is performed over the Moffat model of the MUSE PSF, a possible astrometric shift between the two images, and the sky background level and average sky transmission. An example of difference image is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874619 id=\"132874619\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Searching for transients in imaging data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We searched the difference images for transient sources both manually and automatically. The manual search was performed by three authors (GPS, MB, AR), and identified no sources consistent with being a point source in the difference images. The only sources found were either residuals from the PSF matching close to the centres of bright galaxies, artefacts related to saturated stars, or a small number of residual bad pixels and cosmic rays. The automated search was performed with <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), and found no sources other than PSF matching residuals and artefacts relating to saturated stars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To calibrate the sensitivity of our GMOS search for candidate transients, we injected fake transients into the data in the following manner, and attempted to recover them both manually and automatically. We cut out <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$31\\times 31\\, {\\rm pixel}$|</span> stamps from the GMOS data around the same, unsaturated, high signal-to-noise, stars used for the image quality matching. Each injected source was randomly chosen to be one of these bright star stamps, with the flux scaled accordingly, and shot noise added. To test the efficacy of manual recovery, we generated synthetic data sets, each containing (randomly and unknown to those searching) between 0 and 10 injected sources, with <em>i</em>-band magnitudes drawn uniformly from the range 21 &lt; <em>i</em> &lt; 27. All injected sources with <em>i</em> &lt; 25 were identified by at least two searchers, while no sources with <em>i</em> &gt; 25 were identified by anyone. These results were independent of whether sources were injected randomly within <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|</span> of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), or into faint background galaxies (including the spectroscopically confirmed multiply imaged galaxies) following the methods described by Sharon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We show examples of fake <em>i</em> = 25 point sources injected in to our data in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"132874622\" scrollto-destination=\"132874622\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=D7X7jfFstWdqlJLdLBbfQzBdSgBEEDmWK6JZlPO-dCUp5t0luTmCb~LKORAtdbqPHZ4lTdht-Rfltvq~c0PofHwCktB9UugdjbFObSaa8HIEsUY9BVP0-ZjB3HGj6QOa2VvMkIji5qYIx-4DUFe0dAVnRrYfPp537E4Chn5fPo6eTUum8q8zXm0mA7--pLFaUL7zAsPHqNZqsRL4e8r0VBS-yfWSInCxHvUjK7Kkeiq-o9J1UBrPwzK8gqPyCIb-TldnWnpn0NCTSpp5ktQeyfL~XvWVrSorLv7RxEVxGoeDQfA6Xb0dFDySwl40NDIb~UtsAftsugQhWdHBUgxmPQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example fake i\u00a0= 25 point sources that were injected into the GMOS observations of Abell 3084. Each panel is $4\\times 4\\, {\\rm arcsec}$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874622/stz675fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874622\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=aYuDcKvcAkQX-CDibWG3MCw0SZYtIZv-whn7msw2DtQuutSSLHJq4ejkYwiO~dIqumK~-sm4Z39gBbOv6SgRhavSfBqNQMNOyeudfmNDj-EGVtopyZKPX1QpFMKy5WQGxVA76GpCt7y6S-BBaQA4SKC2u0y0c3-DUre6YvXE7bWpdRBj-gBmN7ij3Ct-KHl0yQhcmI7IurlRvlWAUMYJk9sNgJSEY22lA-51DInoHshwnpYkEAJyzQnH0~rC5d2VWhynEmSH31YX26Yb2K0wpbHwR-GrRjUuPkek-6pzqdvYElWsFv0T~0tdGf2wf9PLzvRPCxBKiQHlrTrUp~GQ5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874622&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example fake <em>i</em>\u00a0= 25 point sources that were injected into the GMOS observations of Abell 3084. Each panel is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$4\\times 4\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a05.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=D7X7jfFstWdqlJLdLBbfQzBdSgBEEDmWK6JZlPO-dCUp5t0luTmCb~LKORAtdbqPHZ4lTdht-Rfltvq~c0PofHwCktB9UugdjbFObSaa8HIEsUY9BVP0-ZjB3HGj6QOa2VvMkIji5qYIx-4DUFe0dAVnRrYfPp537E4Chn5fPo6eTUum8q8zXm0mA7--pLFaUL7zAsPHqNZqsRL4e8r0VBS-yfWSInCxHvUjK7Kkeiq-o9J1UBrPwzK8gqPyCIb-TldnWnpn0NCTSpp5ktQeyfL~XvWVrSorLv7RxEVxGoeDQfA6Xb0dFDySwl40NDIb~UtsAftsugQhWdHBUgxmPQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example fake i\u00a0= 25 point sources that were injected into the GMOS observations of Abell 3084. Each panel is $4\\times 4\\, {\\rm arcsec}$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874622/stz675fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874622\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=aYuDcKvcAkQX-CDibWG3MCw0SZYtIZv-whn7msw2DtQuutSSLHJq4ejkYwiO~dIqumK~-sm4Z39gBbOv6SgRhavSfBqNQMNOyeudfmNDj-EGVtopyZKPX1QpFMKy5WQGxVA76GpCt7y6S-BBaQA4SKC2u0y0c3-DUre6YvXE7bWpdRBj-gBmN7ij3Ct-KHl0yQhcmI7IurlRvlWAUMYJk9sNgJSEY22lA-51DInoHshwnpYkEAJyzQnH0~rC5d2VWhynEmSH31YX26Yb2K0wpbHwR-GrRjUuPkek-6pzqdvYElWsFv0T~0tdGf2wf9PLzvRPCxBKiQHlrTrUp~GQ5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874622&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example fake <em>i</em>\u00a0= 25 point sources that were injected into the GMOS observations of Abell 3084. Each panel is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$4\\times 4\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To test the automated search, we generated 10<sup>4</sup> synthetic datasets comprising sources injected at each integer magnitude in the range 21 \u2264 <em>i</em> \u2264 26. <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> was then run on these synthetic datasets, with the source being detected if <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> finds a source within <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.5\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|</span> of the injected source location. At small angular separations from the BCG (\u03b8<sub>BCG</sub>), the probability of sources being detected is low due to the residuals in the difference images (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The source recovery rate at the very centre (within <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lt 0.5\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|</span> of the BCG) is artificially boosted because <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> detects the residuals at the centre of the BCG (in the absence of an injected source) as a source. However, these scales are generally smaller than the high-magnification region close to the radial critical curve, and therefore the residuals at the centre of the BCG are not a major limiting factor in our analysis.</p>                        <a id=\"132874624\" scrollto-destination=\"132874624\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=i6QTEgHl57Tgw0NXdgVmsDbA8BdKjkKFzLhjhiM6X1SP~AMvYH1WIu7lyJvAuWeoLJYXWWqxaNLlHEMJML9rqDGBR4I1eGG7UdB-i4JiRFhuxqoYQaAjiXJjsmw0cG~nRN4qfUobY3Nc2mMp3AXVxo2k7OCoyZ9cK2DyjGIoYSaVIMoDEManxl61IpuZHs5FUOkYYO1k0v0QYhLhfSu-5yydaQiLq~LEaz0-GoLFPuLFomQayJSWlQFnryvPKYfF~~k-QW-bXekjj0XbdWaM0m6MRkk0vQrPxWaXvcEvdSy7L~~1wA9QCUaBhdjNU72~yC0m923BD39RVP3Pgx53Hw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The recovery fraction of injected sources with different i-band magnitudes (as labelled), as a function of angular separation from the BCG. The solid lines show fractions for sources injected into GMOS observations of Abell 3084, while the dashed lines are for sources injected into the MUSE/HST data for the same cluster. The lines are faded at small radii where the recovery of injected sources is confused by the presence of structured residuals near the BCG centre. The radial distribution of image-plane solid angle magnified sufficiently to reinterpret the LIGO\u2013Virgo detection of GW170814 as originating from z\u00a0= 0.764 is shown by the grey area.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874624/stz675fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=f9IUICXJUwonJyqfYSlzt5Eeoid1OaB5sSBYpyebkDdHyu1-WWFnm1qGbk8DLYVZsztWVUBLJAmFYjucNHMVTdn3RddEk2GFRhgl~NhHdndXOgl9CguvZoJ6NiSEqyxK4cp5XmgjuwlvMHFZzITwZ6XhOBcAH9Lphj8uuBP4zEV3-z83GyN9aM30guGEciL2gTJ2FDtUdx81YpY2kKeEgRWQeo9loPrrpU5nIas1e4xXzu1d61mNfj~p-bs2BJBuRUy~6S0qg9Qu-IGUnuLbSg6buorrw2byzufBC1B~4Ti4Q452dlFE9QCEonDN1Hlf0SxJWi8U5ZV0CvECVpjwdw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874624&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recovery fraction of injected sources with different <em>i</em>-band magnitudes (as labelled), as a function of angular separation from the BCG. The solid lines show fractions for sources injected into GMOS observations of Abell 3084, while the dashed lines are for sources injected into the MUSE/<em>HST</em> data for the same cluster. The lines are faded at small radii where the recovery of injected sources is confused by the presence of structured residuals near the BCG centre. The radial distribution of image-plane solid angle magnified sufficiently to reinterpret the LIGO\u2013Virgo detection of GW170814 as originating from <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.764 is shown by the grey area.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a06.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=i6QTEgHl57Tgw0NXdgVmsDbA8BdKjkKFzLhjhiM6X1SP~AMvYH1WIu7lyJvAuWeoLJYXWWqxaNLlHEMJML9rqDGBR4I1eGG7UdB-i4JiRFhuxqoYQaAjiXJjsmw0cG~nRN4qfUobY3Nc2mMp3AXVxo2k7OCoyZ9cK2DyjGIoYSaVIMoDEManxl61IpuZHs5FUOkYYO1k0v0QYhLhfSu-5yydaQiLq~LEaz0-GoLFPuLFomQayJSWlQFnryvPKYfF~~k-QW-bXekjj0XbdWaM0m6MRkk0vQrPxWaXvcEvdSy7L~~1wA9QCUaBhdjNU72~yC0m923BD39RVP3Pgx53Hw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The recovery fraction of injected sources with different i-band magnitudes (as labelled), as a function of angular separation from the BCG. The solid lines show fractions for sources injected into GMOS observations of Abell 3084, while the dashed lines are for sources injected into the MUSE/HST data for the same cluster. The lines are faded at small radii where the recovery of injected sources is confused by the presence of structured residuals near the BCG centre. The radial distribution of image-plane solid angle magnified sufficiently to reinterpret the LIGO\u2013Virgo detection of GW170814 as originating from z\u00a0= 0.764 is shown by the grey area.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874624/stz675fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=f9IUICXJUwonJyqfYSlzt5Eeoid1OaB5sSBYpyebkDdHyu1-WWFnm1qGbk8DLYVZsztWVUBLJAmFYjucNHMVTdn3RddEk2GFRhgl~NhHdndXOgl9CguvZoJ6NiSEqyxK4cp5XmgjuwlvMHFZzITwZ6XhOBcAH9Lphj8uuBP4zEV3-z83GyN9aM30guGEciL2gTJ2FDtUdx81YpY2kKeEgRWQeo9loPrrpU5nIas1e4xXzu1d61mNfj~p-bs2BJBuRUy~6S0qg9Qu-IGUnuLbSg6buorrw2byzufBC1B~4Ti4Q452dlFE9QCEonDN1Hlf0SxJWi8U5ZV0CvECVpjwdw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874624&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recovery fraction of injected sources with different <em>i</em>-band magnitudes (as labelled), as a function of angular separation from the BCG. The solid lines show fractions for sources injected into GMOS observations of Abell 3084, while the dashed lines are for sources injected into the MUSE/<em>HST</em> data for the same cluster. The lines are faded at small radii where the recovery of injected sources is confused by the presence of structured residuals near the BCG centre. The radial distribution of image-plane solid angle magnified sufficiently to reinterpret the LIGO\u2013Virgo detection of GW170814 as originating from <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.764 is shown by the grey area.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sources at the typical 5\u03c3 point source sensitivity of our GMOS data (<em>i</em> \u2243 25) are detected with the expected \u223c80\u2009per\u2009cent completeness at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm BCG}\\, \\gtrsim \\, 5\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>, and sources at <em>i</em> \u2243 24 are detectable right down to angular separations of a few arcseconds. We put this into context by plotting in grey in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> the solid angle that is magnified by the amount required to reinterpret the strain signal from GW170814 as coming from <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.764, which is the redshift at which the lens model of Abell 3084 is most robust (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>), also taking into account the uncertainty on the luminosity distance to GW170814. Use of <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.764 is by way of example only, and motivated by not wishing to extrapolate the lens model to redshifts at which it is not constrained. The peaks at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm BCG}\\simeq 4\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm BCG}\\simeq 12\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|</span> correspond to the radial and tangential critical curves, respectively (see the inner and outer red curves in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). Our search is therefore sensitive at &gt;80\u2009per\u2009cent completeness to point sources at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$i\\, \\lesssim \\, 24$|</span> that are adjacent to either critical curve and to point sources at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$i\\, \\lesssim \\, 25$|</span> that are adjacent to the tangential critical curve.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We performed similar manual and automated tests with MUSE images, injecting sources into the inner <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$15\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|</span> of the Abell 3084 MUSE/<em>HST</em> difference image, obtaining similar results to the GMOS tests described above. As a consequence of the smaller field of view of MUSE compared to GMOS, we did not have a large number of bright stars to use as templates for point sources, but instead used the best-fitting Moffat profile discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-6\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.6</a>. We interpret the slight shortfall in the fraction of fake sources that are recovered from the MUSE/<em>HST</em> difference images relative to the GMOS images as being caused by the flux sensitivity of the short <em>HST</em> observation being inferior to that of the MUSE observations, after smoothing the <em>HST</em> data to match the ground-based seeing.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874627 id=\"132874627\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Searching for transients in MUSE data cubes</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the search for continuum sources based on pseudo-images created from the MUSE datacubes, we have performed an automatic search for emission lines across all wavelengths. This is done using the <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> detection software, which has been used in the past to automatically search for line emitters in MUSE blank fields (Drake et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>) as well as lensing cluster fields (Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Mahler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> is publicly available as part of the MUSE Python Data Analysis Framework (Conseil et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) software suite. It is a <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span>-based detection tool based on a continuum-subtracted datacube where each wavelength plane is replaced by its corresponding narrow-band image, optimized for the detection of typical <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm FWHM}=150\\, \\mathrm{km\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> line width line sources. The sensitivity of <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> in recovering point-source line emitters has been extensively tested by Drake et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>) in the MUSE Ultra Deep Field (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and we rescale their results to the exposure times of individual datacubes in each night. The values show that our search is complete for line fluxes brighter than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"132874629\" scrollto-destination=\"132874629\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=RYOtYpaMUdPoDLMu6jcbOmAT6RXkwHfTEsPxbp9UvihwHxj9Q3yvbEZIKi9NsQEgxBGdl9e5rothjTA9VFoK9sugqvLPQu79UETh~jYVKDlC9kbOKJRjpxxXi1Bmrlxd0eRd~iA7vYelAjgFUdDsleyQvwBS~vsTmbWXV6sfiEytmEynw7BgyBHAW25EvrBlCwAxWgJFmepoE2g4rB0RrLXwF0bEBePHXIoVGkumxmmH4KpeFMQes06pShTNUMmqnNr1RV7OIMiGdz0s0BS0uEXJe5U1pYXGxf26~dWAfDxLpdSkoOu7xknn5UCL5wNmJ~mqeIdZQBABHR-P0mH4TQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Emission line sensitivity in our search for transients in the individual (per night) MUSE datacubes. Presented is the average completeness level of recovering emission line point sources with muselet as a function of line flux, which slightly varies across the cube as a function of the wavelength range.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874629/stz675fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874629\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=N4lHY30amMPwRFPGAP9OnhD8uVQEMLAt1HXfAigf2nX49HMHjeEjboeOjHf14tFdf1gqzy66jAeW9ohTvxuJbk8XvnEchrNEdB6XmAme-FgMZ~Q-bpS2Um8jvUSiltCfYs-XVRasL9JDYw~tkxQY3tLIw-skVUy41AY8GADgFNYkCO2YyteAe1NLnWvxsmxhDUBQ60P0Dyrhr4u18URveJMi5gdB9YsklK2s0xt~ZmBlj3r927g1j8UHK10fXP8yR6EU5y-BqH2gzFctakU4KCDrJ0NYxmGnyYfjKKLj9EZC02bEr-1AWLWpAgkIr-C0qij8~VNbjDod8vOWZtmz-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874629&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Emission line sensitivity in our search for transients in the individual (per night) MUSE datacubes. Presented is the average completeness level of recovering emission line point sources with <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> as a function of line flux, which slightly varies across the cube as a function of the wavelength range.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a07.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=RYOtYpaMUdPoDLMu6jcbOmAT6RXkwHfTEsPxbp9UvihwHxj9Q3yvbEZIKi9NsQEgxBGdl9e5rothjTA9VFoK9sugqvLPQu79UETh~jYVKDlC9kbOKJRjpxxXi1Bmrlxd0eRd~iA7vYelAjgFUdDsleyQvwBS~vsTmbWXV6sfiEytmEynw7BgyBHAW25EvrBlCwAxWgJFmepoE2g4rB0RrLXwF0bEBePHXIoVGkumxmmH4KpeFMQes06pShTNUMmqnNr1RV7OIMiGdz0s0BS0uEXJe5U1pYXGxf26~dWAfDxLpdSkoOu7xknn5UCL5wNmJ~mqeIdZQBABHR-P0mH4TQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Emission line sensitivity in our search for transients in the individual (per night) MUSE datacubes. Presented is the average completeness level of recovering emission line point sources with muselet as a function of line flux, which slightly varies across the cube as a function of the wavelength range.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874629/stz675fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874629\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=N4lHY30amMPwRFPGAP9OnhD8uVQEMLAt1HXfAigf2nX49HMHjeEjboeOjHf14tFdf1gqzy66jAeW9ohTvxuJbk8XvnEchrNEdB6XmAme-FgMZ~Q-bpS2Um8jvUSiltCfYs-XVRasL9JDYw~tkxQY3tLIw-skVUy41AY8GADgFNYkCO2YyteAe1NLnWvxsmxhDUBQ60P0Dyrhr4u18URveJMi5gdB9YsklK2s0xt~ZmBlj3r927g1j8UHK10fXP8yR6EU5y-BqH2gzFctakU4KCDrJ0NYxmGnyYfjKKLj9EZC02bEr-1AWLWpAgkIr-C0qij8~VNbjDod8vOWZtmz-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874629&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Emission line sensitivity in our search for transients in the individual (per night) MUSE datacubes. Presented is the average completeness level of recovering emission line point sources with <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> as a function of line flux, which slightly varies across the cube as a function of the wavelength range.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Removing obvious false detections (sharper than the spatial and/or spectral PSF) through visual inspection, we compare the detection of line emitters found in each datacube as well as the combination of both nights with the reference <em>HST</em> image. The only sources appearing as line emitters in MUSE and absent from <em>HST</em> are clear Lyman-\u03b1 emitters with strong equivalent width identified from the shape of their spectral lines and/or as multiple images.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874631 id=\"132874631\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now discuss the empirical sensitivity of our observations of strong-lensing cluster cores in the context of the plausible EM counterparts to CBC GW sources. We first discuss the cancellation of the inverse square law by lens magnification for strongly lensed point source EM counterparts to GWs (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>), and then apply this to kilonova-like EM counterparts (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>), and EM counterparts that might resemble emission from known low mass X-ray binaries within the Milky Way during outburst (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874633 id=\"132874633\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 The inverse square law and lens magnification</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Consider a hypothetical GW source that is inferred to be at a luminosity distance <em>D</em><sub>L,\u03bc\u00a0= 1</sub> assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1, and that has an EM counterpart of absolute magnitude <em>M</em> in an arbitrary pass band. If this is actually a distant source at <em>D</em><sub>L,true</sub> that is gravitationally magnified by \u03bc &gt; 1, then its apparent magnitude in a pass band that probes the same rest-frame wavelength range as the pass band relevant to <em>M</em> (or, equivalently, assuming <em>k</em>-corrections are negligible), is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nm=M+5\\log (D_{\\rm L,true})-5-2.5\\log (\\mu), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>with <em>D</em><sub>L,true</sub> expressed in units of parsecs. As discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>, the lens magnification that appears in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>) is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mu =\\left(\\frac{D_{\\rm L,true}}{D_{{\\rm L},\\mu =1}}\\right)^2. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>The apparent magnitude of the EM counterpart of a lensed GW therefore depends only on the absolute magnitude of the counterpart and the luminosity distance at which the source is placed when (incorrectly) assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nm=M+5\\log (D_{{\\rm L},\\mu =1})-5. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>The apparent magnitude of a lensed EM counterpart is therefore set by the initial analysis of the signal detected by LIGO\u2013Virgo assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1. Therefore, observations capable of detecting a given EM counterpart located at <em>D</em><sub>L,\u03bc\u00a0= 1</sub> are also able to detect the same type of counterpart if it is lensed, independent of the true redshift.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874635 id=\"132874635\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Kilonovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Optical follow-up observations of BH\u2013BH sources have so far generally aimed to achieve the sensitivity required to detect a kilonova at <em>D</em><sub>L,\u03bc\u00a0= 1</sub> (e.g. Cowperthwaite et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Soares-Santos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Arcavi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Yoshida et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Doctor et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Utsumi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We therefore consider how bright a kilonova-like counterpart to GW170814 would have been if it had been lensed. The kilonova counterpart to GW170817 had an absolute magnitude in optical bands of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M\\, \\lesssim \\, {-13.5}$|</span> in the few days after discovery (e.g. Villar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Arcavi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We therefore adopt <em>M</em> \u2243 \u221213.5 in the rest-frame <em>B/V/R-</em>bands as a template for our calculations. If GW170814 was strongly lensed, and had a kilonova-like EM counterpart, then based on its inferred luminosity distance, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{{\\rm L},\\mu =1}=580^{+160}_{-210}\\, \\mathrm{Mpc}$|</span> (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>), it would have an apparent magnitude of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m\\simeq \\operatorname{24-26}$|</span> in the rest-frame <em>B/V/R</em>-bands independent of its luminosity distance. Our observations reach a depth of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m\\simeq \\operatorname{25-26}$|</span> (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), with a sensitivity to transient sources in our difference image analysis of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m\\simeq \\operatorname{24-25}$|</span> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim80{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> completeness. These sensitivities are in the observer-frame <em>V</em><sub>606</sub> \u2212 and <em>i</em> bands, and can thus be compared with the rest-frame bands quoted above for sources at <em>z</em> \u2243 1. It should therefore have been possible to detect a kilonova-like EM counterpart if GW170814 was strongly lensed by one of the clusters that we observed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A kilonova-like EM counterpart to GW170814 is more plausible if GW170814 actually comprised one or more NS in an NS\u2013NS or NS\u2013BH system. The primary means of identifying a GW source as an NS\u2013NS, NS\u2013BH, or BH\u2013BH is from the inferred component masses, as NSs have a maximum mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lt \\, 3\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|</span> (Rhoades\u00a0&amp; Ruffini <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1974</a>; Kalogera\u00a0&amp; Baym <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Margalit\u00a0&amp; Metzger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> For a particular GW signal, the inferred rest-frame mass of the compact objects is inversely proportional to (1 + <em>z</em>), where <em>z</em> is the redshift of the GW source. Therefore, the rest-frame mass of GW sources would be revised downwards from the initial estimate by LIGO\u2013Virgo, if they are subsequently identified as being strongly lensed. The source frame masses of the individual BHs that comprise GW170814 are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$30.7^{+5.7}_{-3.0}\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$25.3^{+2.9}_{-4.1}\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|</span> (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), which correspond to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }34$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }28\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|</span> in the detector frame, i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim \\, 9$|</span> times larger than the maximum NS mass. Therefore, if GW170814 were strongly lensed, then it would have to be at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z\\, \\gtrsim \\, 8$|</span> for one or both of the two BHs to be reinterpreted as an NS. This implies a lens magnification of \u03bc \u2273 10<sup>4</sup>, which is possible for point sources located behind galaxy cluster lenses (Miralda-Escude <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Our observations and difference image analysis yielded no transient sources in the strong-lensing regions of Abell 3084 and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 down to <em>m</em>\u00a0= 25. Therefore, if we assume that the rest-frame ultraviolet luminosity of a kilonova-like EM counterpart is similar to the rest-frame optical luminosity of GW170817, we can exclude the interpretation of GW170817 as an NS\u2013NS or NS\u2013BH merger at <em>z</em> &gt; 8 that has been strongly lensed by either of these clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">More generally, our analysis shows that the cancellation of the inverse square law by the degeneracy between luminosity distance and lens magnification has important implications for the EM follow-up of GW sources. Specifically, that the detection of EM counterparts to lensed NS\u2013NS and NS\u2013BH sources is within the reach of deep ground-based optical observations with 8-m class telescopes. Our difference image analysis is sensitive to transients as faint as <em>i</em> \u2243 25 and are thus sensitive to kilonova-like counterparts to lensed sources that are initially identified at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{{\\rm L},\\mu =1}\\simeq 500\\, \\mathrm{Mpc}$|\u2060</span>, independent of their true distance.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the future, it may be more fruitful to search for lensed optical kilonova-like counterparts to GW sources initially identified as low-mass BH\u2013BH systems, with individual BH masses of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lt 10\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|</span> because such lower masses imply a less extreme lens magnification. For example, GW170608 (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017h</a>) would have been an ideal target for our observing programme, if we had commenced our observing programmes at VLT and Gemini just a few months earlier. GW170608 comprised (assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1) two BHs of masses <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10.9^{+5.3}_{-1.7}\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.6^{+1.3}_{-2.1}\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, respectively, at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z=0.07^{+0.02}_{-0.02}$|\u2060</span>, which corresponds to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{{\\rm L},\\mu =1}=320_{-110}^{+120}\\, \\mathrm{Mpc}$|</span> (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). Following the reasoning outlined above, it is possible that this is a lensed NS\u2013NS source at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z\\simeq \\operatorname{2-5}$|\u2060</span>, which is magnified by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu \\simeq \\operatorname{10^3-10^4}$|\u2060</span>. This level of magnification is similar to that suffered by the strongly lensed individual blue giant star dubbed \u2018Icarus\u2019 (Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). A kilonova-like counterpart to GW170608 would have an apparent magnitude of <em>m</em> \u2243 24 if it is strongly lensed, independent of its redshift. This is brighter than discussed above for GW170814, but still sufficiently faint to be beyond the reach of most of the current generation of wide-field searches for EM counterparts (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874640 id=\"132874640\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Low mass X-ray binaries</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We also consider the possibility of detecting an EM counterpart that is much fainter than a kilonova. A BH\u2013BH merger in vacuum is not expected to emit any EM radiation; however, numerous theoretical ideas for EM counterparts to BH\u2013BH mergers not in vacuum have been proposed following the detection of GW150914 (e.g. Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Loeb <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lyutikov <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Morsony, Workman\u00a0&amp; Ryan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Murase et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Perna, Lazzati\u00a0&amp; Giacomazzo <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Woosley <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Yamazaki, Asano\u00a0&amp; Ohira <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Bartos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Dai, McKinney\u00a0&amp; Miller <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; de Mink\u00a0&amp; King <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Janiuk et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ryan\u00a0&amp; MacFadyen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Stone, Metzger\u00a0&amp; Haiman <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). By way of illustration, we adopt a simple model of an EM counterpart, apply equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>), and compare with the sensitivity of our search.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We speculate that low mass BH X-ray Binaries (LMXRB) during outburst in the Milky Way could provide an illustrative upper limit on the brightness of the EM counterparts to BH\u2013BH mergers. The brightest LMXRB seen to date is V404\u2009Cyg, with a BH mass of 9\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> and peak extinction corrected absolute <em>V</em>-band magnitude during outburst of <em>M<sub>V</sub></em> \u2243 \u22124.7 (e.g. van Paradijs\u00a0&amp; McClintock <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Bernardini et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We further assume that the luminosity of the accretion disc is proportional to the mass of the BH, and the accretion rate as a fraction of the Eddington limit. Therefore, combining these assumptions with the dependence of BH mass on redshift (discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>), gives the following expression for the estimated absolute magnitude <em>M</em> of the EM counterpart to a lensed BH\u2013BH merger: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nM=M_0-2.5\\, \\log \\left(\\frac{\\Lambda }{\\Lambda _0}\\, .\\, \\frac{\\mathbb {M}_{{\\rm f},\\mu =1}}{\\mathbb {M}_0}\\, .\\, \\frac{1+z_{\\mu =1}}{1+z}\\right), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <em>z</em> is the true redshift of the lensed BH\u2013BH, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {M}_{{\\rm f},\\mu =1}$|</span> is the final BH mass of a BH\u2013BH merger inferred assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1, \u039b denotes accretion rate as a fraction of the Eddington limit, and we adopt <em>M</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0= \u22124.7, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {M}_0=9\\mathrm\\,{\\mathrm{ M}_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, and \u039b<sub>0</sub>\u00a0= 1 for V404\u2009Cyg. Substituting equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>) into equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>), and adopting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbb {M}_{\\rm f,\\mu =1}\\simeq 53\\, \\mathrm{M_\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, <em>z</em><sub>\u03bc\u00a0= 1</sub> \u2243 0.12 for GW170814 (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), a nominal source redshift of <em>z</em> \u2243 1, and \u039b\u00a0= 1, gives <em>m</em> \u2243 33. This is a factor \u2243 10<sup>3</sup>\u221210<sup>4</sup> fainter than the transient point sources that we are able to recover in our difference imaging (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>), which is unsurprising given that we did not set out to detect such faint EM counterparts. Moreover, to underline how challenging any possible detection of an EM counterpart to a BH\u2013BH would be, \u039b \u2273 10 would be required to bring the apparent magnitude of a source within reach of an observation of depth comparable with the Hubble Ultra Deep Field, i.e. <em>m</em> \u2243 30. Alternatively, follow-up observations of a GW170814-like source initially placed at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\rm L,\\mu =1}=170\\, {\\rm Mpc}$|</span> and with \u039b\u00a0= 1 would also be detectable at <em>m</em> \u2243 30, based on this speculative V404\u2009Cyg-like scenario. Finally, in all of this discussion, we have assumed that <em>k</em>-corrections are negligible, as the absolute magnitudes are in the (effectively) rest-frame <em>V</em>-band of sources at <em>z</em> \u2243 1 that we observe in the <em>i</em>-band.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874643 id=\"132874643\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the nights immediately following the announcement of the detection of GW170814, we observed two strong-lensing cluster cores \u2013 Abell 3084 and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 \u2013 identified using the sky localization available from the LVC. Our observations were conducted with the GMOS and MUSE instruments on the Gemini-South telescope and VLT, respectively. The data reach a sensitivity to point sources of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m(5\\sigma)\\simeq \\operatorname{25-26}$|\u2060</span>, and our search for transient sources is sensitive down to <em>m</em>\u00a0= 25 in the continuum and line fluxes of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>. We detect no credible candidate transient sources in the data down to these limits. This is the most sensitive search to date for EM counterparts to GW sources, independent of considerations of possible lens amplification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens magnification suffered by a lensed GW source cancels out the inverse square law, and therefore the apparent magnitude of a point source EM counterpart of given luminosity is set by the luminosity distance inferred from the GW data assuming no lens magnification. The apparent magnitude of EM counterparts to lensed GW sources is independent of the true redshift of the source. We therefore show, as a proof of concept, that we can exclude the idea that GW170814 is an NS\u2013BH or NS\u2013NS source at <em>z</em> &gt; 8 that is lensed by either of these clusters. We also show that observations with 30-m class and/or space-based telescopes will be required to conduct meaningful searches for lensed EM counterparts to BH\u2013BH sources. We will consider the details of such observing strategies, and those required for lensed NS\u2013NS and NS\u2013BH sources in a future article.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In summary, we have confirmed the feasibility of searching for EM counterparts to candidate lensed GW sources with ground-based 8-m class telescopes, and described some important considerations for future development of this new observing strategy within the rapidly growing field of GW astronomy.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874647 id=\"132874647\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">GPS dedicates this article to the memory of Robert Smith, and thanks Olivia Mueller for her support during August 2017. GPS also thanks Gary Mamon and colleagues at the Institut d\u2019Astrophysique de Paris for their warm welcome during the later stages of writing this article, and Alberto Vecchio for his advice and support. We thank Iair Arcavi and Leo Singer for assistance with Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, Alyssa Drake for providing us with the results of completeness tests to blindly detect line emitters within MUSE datacubes using <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>, and Chris Done and Sylvain Chaty for helpful discussions about low mass X-ray binaries. We thank the staff and Directors of the Gemini and La Silla Paranal Observatories for their superb support of our observing programmes and awards of Director\u2019s Discretionary time, respectively. We acknowledge support from the Science and Technology Facilities Council through the following grants: ST/N000633/1 (GPS, MB, CPLB, WMF), ST/L00075X/1, ST/P000451/1 (MJ), and ST/K005014/1 (JV). JR acknowledges support from the ERC starting grant 336736-CALENDS. RM acknowledges support from the Royal Society.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874649 id=\"132874649\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Based on observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF on behalf of the Gemini partnership: the National Science Foundation (United States), the National Research Council (Canada), CONICYT (Chile), Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnolog\u00eda e Innovaci\u00f3n Productiva (Argentina), and Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia e Inova\u00e7\u00e3o (Brazil).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Based on observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory under programme ID 299.A-5028.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.baryons.org/ezgal/\" target=\"_blank\">www.baryons.org/ezgal/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">NSs could also be disambiguated from the imprint of tidal effects on the signal. These are difficult to measure, and could not be conclusively identified for GW170817 despite its high signal-to-noise ratio, without assuming that the source comprised NSs (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017c</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>).</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874654 id=\"132874654\" class=\"backreferences-title\" data-legacy-id=ref1>REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib2\" data-legacy-id=\"bib2\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib2\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib2\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib2\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">B. arcsec}$|\u2060</span>, estimated from the magnitude at which the median photometric uncertainty is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.2\\, {\\rm magnitudes}$|\u2060</span>. content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Mean full width at half-maximum of point sources in the reduced data, with a typical error on the mean of <span arcsec}$|\u2060</span>, estimated from the magnitude at which the median photometric uncertainty is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.2\\, {\\rm magnitudes}$|\u2060</span>. <script type='text/javascript'>\r\n            var gptAdSlots = [];\r\n            googletag.cmd.push(function() {\r\n                    \r\n                    var mapping_ad1 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([1024, 0], [[970, 90], [728, 90]])\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .addSize([0, 0], [320, 50])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad1\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Behind_Ad1',\r\n                            [[970, 90], [728, 90], [320, 50]], 'adBlockHeader')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad1)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                    var mapping_ad2 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [[300, 250], [300, 600], [160, 600]])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad2\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Behind_Ad2',\r\n                            [[300, 250], [160, 600], [300, 600]], 'adBlockMainBodyTop')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad2)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                    var mapping_ad3 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [[300, 250], [300, 600], [160, 600]])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad3\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Behind_Ad3',\r\n                        [[300, 250], [160, 600], [300, 600]], 'adBlockMainBodyBottom')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad3)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                    \r\n                var mapping_ad4 = googletag.sizeMapping()\r\n                        .addSize([0,0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .addSize([768, 0], [728, 90])\r\n                        .build();\r\n                    gptAdSlots[\"ad4\"] = googletag.defineSlot('/116097782/mnras_Behind_Ad4',\r\n                        [728, 90], 'adBlockFooter')\r\n                        .defineSizeMapping(mapping_ad4)\r\n                        .addService(googletag.pubads());\r\n                    \r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().addEventListener('slotRenderEnded', function (event) {\r\n;                    if (!event.isEmpty) {\r\n                        $('.js-' + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).each(function () {\r\n                            if ($(this).find('iframe').length) {\r\n                                $(this).removeClass('hide');\r\n                            }\r\n                        });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"article\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"mnras/article/485/4/5180/5372447\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n
