      </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874575 id=\"132874575\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present observations of two strong-lensing galaxy clusters located within the 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible sky localization maps released following LIGO\u2013Virgo\u2019s discovery of the binary black hole (BH\u2013BH) gravitational wave (GW) source GW170814. Our objectives were (1) to search for candidate electromagnetic (EM) counterparts to GW170814 under the hypothesis that it was strongly lensed, and thus more distant and less massive than inferred by LIGO\u2013Virgo, and (2) to demonstrate the feasibility of rapid target of opportunity observations to search for faint lensed transient point sources in crowded cluster cores located within GW sky localizations. Commencing 20\u2009h after discovery, and continuing over 12 nights, we observed Abell 3084 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.22) and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.46) with GMOS on the Gemini-South telescope, and Abell 3084 with MUSE on ESO\u2019s Very Large Telescope. We detect no candidate EM counterparts in these data. Calibration of our photometric analysis methods using simulations yields 5\u03c3 detection limits for transients in difference images of the cores of these clusters of <em>i</em>\u00a0= 25. This is the most sensitive photometric search to date for counterparts to GW sources, and rules out the possibility that GW170814 was lensed by these clusters with a kilonova-like EM counterpart. Based on the detector frame masses of the compact objects, and assuming that at least one neutron star (NS) is required in the merging system to produce a kilonova-like counterpart, implies that GW170814 was neither an NS\u2013NS nor NS\u2013BH merger at <em>z</em> &gt; 8 lensed by either of these clusters. Also, in the first ever emission line search for counterparts to GW sources, we detected no lines down to a 5\u03c3 detection limit of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational waves&quot;\">gravitational waves</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational waves: individual: GW170814&quot;\">gravitational waves: individual: GW170814</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual Abell\u20093084, SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual Abell\u20093084, SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874577 id=\"132874577\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Observational astronomy gained a new tool with the first direct detection of gravitational waves (GWs; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016c</a>). GWs have already provided new insights into the properties of compact binaries and the nature of gravity (e.g. Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">d,f</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) that complement those accessible to EM observations. In the case of GW170817 (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017c</a>), the first GW signal from a binary neutron star (NS\u2013NS) coalescence was followed by observations of a counterpart across the electromagnetic (EM) spectrum (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017e</a>). These multimessenger observations permitted new tests of general relativity (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017f</a>), measurement of the Hubble constant (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017d</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018c</a>), and yielded information on NS physics (e.g. Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017g</a>; Bauswein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Levan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Margalit\u00a0&amp; Metzger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>)</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Optical follow-up observations of stellar mass compact binary coalescence (CBC) sources of GWs are challenging because of the large sky localization uncertainties inherent in the LIGO\u2013Virgo data analysis. With only two GW detectors, sky localizations can be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }\\operatorname{100-1000}\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|</span> (Singer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Berry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>); adding additional detectors to the network improves sky localization (Veitch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>; Pankow et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and enhances 3D localization (Singer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Del Pozzo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Towards the end of LIGO\u2013Virgo\u2019s second observing run (O2) in 2017, when all three detectors were operational, the sky localizations from LIGO and Virgo for their triple-detector observations were <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }\\operatorname{20-90}\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|</span> (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). The largest cameras on 4-m and 8-m class optical telescopes have fields of view of up to a few square degrees. It is therefore time consuming to search thoroughly the error regions of even the best localized GW sources, especially in the case of binary black hole (BH\u2013BH) mergers, for which any EM counterparts are expected to be faint or non-existent. Despite these challenges, early observations of BH\u2013BH merger sky localization error regions have been invaluable testing grounds for optical follow-up (e.g. Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016g</a>; Cowperthwaite et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Soares-Santos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Yoshida et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Doctor et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Utsumi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Strategies that aim to overcome the challenges include optimizing the tiling and scheduling of wide-field searches (Coughlin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and targeting the follow-up observations on stellar mass selected galaxies located within the 3D GW localizations (Nissanke, Kasliwal\u00a0&amp; Georgieva <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Fan, Messenger\u00a0&amp; Heng <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Hanna, Mandel\u00a0&amp; Vousden <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Gehrels et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The latter approach was deployed to great success in the earliest identification of the optical counterpart to the NS\u2013NS signal GW170817 (Coulter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The luminosity distance to CBC sources is measured to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\operatorname{30-40}$|</span>\u2009per\u2009cent precision from LIGO\u2013Virgo data (Berry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016e</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). Gravitational lensing, and in particular strong lensing (i.e. multiple imaging), is a possible source of systematic bias in these inferred luminosity distances because the amplitude of the strain signal <em>A</em> depends on both lens magnification \u03bc, and luminosity distance <em>D</em><sub>L</sub>: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$A\\propto |\\mu |^{0.5}D_{\\rm L}^{-1}$|</span> (hereafter we use \u03bc to denote |\u03bc|). Therefore, lens magnification allows sources from greater distances to be observed, and also means that the luminosity distance to a lensed source inferred assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1 is underestimated by a factor \u03bc<sup>0.5</sup> (Wang, Stebbins\u00a0&amp; Turner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). The redshift distribution of the known galaxy and cluster strong lenses peaks close to <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.3 (e.g. Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>), which corresponds to a luminosity distance of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\rm L}=1.6\\, {\\rm Gpc}$|\u2060</span>. For a GW source that is initially interpreted as being located at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\rm L}\\, \\lesssim \\, 500\\, {\\rm Mpc}$|</span> to be reinterpreted as being strongly lensed implies that it must be magnified by a factor of \u03bc \u2273 10. The systematic bias in the inferred distance also means that the masses of the source, which are calculated using the inferred source redshift (Krolak\u00a0&amp; Schutz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>), are overestimated by a factor (1 + <em>z</em><sub>\u03bc\u00a0= 1</sub>)/(1 + <em>z</em>), where <em>z</em><sub>\u03bc\u00a0= 1</sub> is the redshift inferred assuming \u03bc\u00a0= 1, and <em>z</em> is the true redshift of the lensed source. Therefore, while lensing does complicate the measurement of distance, identification of a lensed source with LIGO\u2013Virgo would provide a glimpse of the CBC population at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z\\, \\gtrsim \\, 1$|\u2060</span>, well in advance of third-generation GW detectors.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A strongly lensed GW would travel to the Earth along multiple paths through the foreground mass concentration, and thus in principle could be detected on more than one occasion by LIGO\u2013Virgo, as would any EM counterpart. These paths differ in length, leading to a time delay between detections of consecutive signals up to several years (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). Multiple detections of a single GW source, will create unique scientific opportunities with important advantages over previous work and important new challenges to overcome. The transient nature of GW events/detections mean that EM follow-up observations will not require expensive long-term monitoring programmes that are typical of time delay cosmography with lensed quasars. Moreover, the submillisecond precision to which the arrival time of GW signals is measured by LIGO\u2013Virgo (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">d</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">e</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>) will lead to a measured precision on the time delay between the arrival of lensed GW signals that is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim \\, 8$|</span> orders of magnitude superior to that achievable with supernovae or quasars (e.g. Fohlmeister et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Therefore, in principle, strongly lensed GWs will yield unprecedented constraints on the distribution of dark and luminous matter in the gravitational lens, and a new and highly accurate measurement of the Hubble parameter (Liao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). However, lens substructure and micro-lensing may reduce the precision of such measurements (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a> and references therein; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Tie\u00a0&amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), and therefore work to address such issues will be required. Comparing the time delay between EM and GW images will also enable the propagation speed of light and gravity to be compared (Collett\u00a0&amp; Bacon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Fan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Multiple detections of the same GW source will also enable new constraints on GW polarizations because the number of detectors that observe the same GW signal would grow with the number of the detections of the strongly lensed event (cf. Chatziioannou, Yunes\u00a0&amp; Cornish <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The probability that a GW source detected to date by LIGO\u2013Virgo is strongly lensed is small because a tiny fraction of the sky is magnified sufficiently (\u03bc \u2273 10, as discussed above) to reinterpret the detected strain signal as originating from a source beyond the lens population. For example, Hilbert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) estimate that the source plane optical depth to \u03bc &gt; 10 for sources at <em>z</em> \u2264 2 is \u03c4<sub>S</sub> \u2272 10<sup>\u22125</sup>. Therefore, whilst estimates for the rate of detection of lensed GW sources vary, there is a broad consensus that the expected rate during O1 and O2 is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\ll 1\\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, and will rise to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim ~1\\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}$|</span> when LIGO\u2013Virgo reach design sensitivity in the early 2020s (Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It will be difficult to identify that a GW source is strongly lensed from the LIGO\u2013Virgo signal alone (Hannuksela et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This is because the overestimated mass of the compact objects may not appear anomalous, and the GW sky localization uncertainties dwarf the solid angle subtended by the strong-lensing regions of galaxies, groups, and clusters by many orders of magnitude. Therefore, strong evidence beyond that available from the strain signal measured by LIGO\u2013Virgo will be needed to outweigh the low prior expectation that a given GW signal was strongly lensed. Identification of an EM counterpart to a GW source adjacent to the critical curve of a strong lens, and detection of a subsequent image of the same source would provide such evidence, and thus establish that a GW had been strongly lensed. This would allow the correct source parameters to be inferred, and enable the science outlined above.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Current observations and theoretical predictions point to galaxy clusters dominating the optical depth to gravitationally magnifying point sources by \u03bc \u2265 10. On the observational side, all strongly lensed images of quasars found by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) that are magnified by \u03bc &gt; 10 are lensed by galaxy clusters (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>. In contrast, individual galaxy lenses have thus far been shown to produce only low magnification strongly lensed quasar images, i.e. \u03bc &lt; 10 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Kayo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Morokuma et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Ofek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This picture is supported by theoretical work, notably that of Hilbert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), whose optical depth to strong lensing is dominated by haloes of mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> &gt; 10<sup>13\u2009</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>, i.e. galaxy groups and clusters. However, the number of highly magnified quasars seen by SDSS is small, and Hilbert et\u00a0al.\u2019s predictions pre-date modern cosmological hydrodynamical simulations. Therefore, more theoretical and observational work is needed to clarify the relative contribution of galaxy- and cluster-scale haloes to high-magnification lensing of point sources such as CBCs. In Robertson et\u00a0al. (in preparation), we will consider the optical depth to strong lensing as a function of halo mass based on cosmological hydrodynamical simulations, and in this article we concentrate on optical observations that explore the strong-lensing interpretation of BH\u2013BH mergers detected by LIGO\u2013Virgo.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We introduce a new observing strategy for identifying optical counterparts to GW sources \u2013 observations of strong-lensing galaxy cluster cores located within LIGO\u2013Virgo GW sky localization maps. We describe our first implementation of this strategy via rapid target of opportunity (ToO) observations with the Gemini-South telescope<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> and ESO\u2019s Very Large Telescope<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> (VLT) in the nights immediately following the discovery of the BH\u2013BH source GW170814 (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>). Our observations targeted known strong-lensing galaxy clusters, selected from the list compiled by Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). The main goals of our observations were to test the feasibility of searching for optical transients in rapid follow-up observations with small field-of-view instruments (which are well matched to cluster cores, and not routinely used for discovery of transient objects) on 8-m class telescopes, and to search in earnest for candidate EM counterparts to putative strongly lensed GW sources. The large aperture of Gemini-South and VLT, and the absence of any requirement for us to explore the wider sky localization, enabled us to conduct deep observations that are sensitive to strongly lensed EM counterparts down to <em>i</em>\u00a0= 25 independent of the actual source redshift. Our strategy therefore benefits from greater sensitivity than conventional searches, at the expense of a much smaller survey volume.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We describe the details of our observing strategy, observations, and data reduction in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, explain how we generate difference images, and search for candidate optical counterparts, and state our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, discuss our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, and summarize in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We assume a flat cosmology with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0=67.9\\, \\mathrm{km\\, s^{-1}}\\, \\mathrm{Mpc}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0= 0.3065 (Ade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). All celestial coordinates are stated at the J2000 epoch, and all magnitudes are stated in the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874587 id=\"132874587\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874588 id=\"132874588\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Observing strategy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We aim to conduct the most sensitive search to date for optical emission from CBC sources of GWs, under the hypothesis that the objects that we target have been strongly lensed by a massive foreground galaxy cluster. We therefore select known, spectroscopically confirmed strong-lensing clusters located close to the peak probability of the sky localizations of LIGO Scientific-Virgo Collaboration (LVC) CBC alerts. The strong-lensing regions of these clusters span <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }\\operatorname{1-2}\\, {\\rm arcmin}^2$|</span> on the sky, and are thus perfectly matched to instruments on ground-based 8-m class telescopes, including the GMOS instruments on the Gemini-North and South telescopes, and MUSE on VLT.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The most common GW sources are the coalescence of BH\u2013BHs. Optical emission from BH\u2013BHs is expected to be faint or non-existent (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>, and references therein). Searches for optical emission from BH\u2013BH mergers have typically reached sensitivity limits in the observer-frame <em>V</em>/<em>R</em>/<em>I</em>-bands of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m\\, \\lesssim \\, 22$|</span> with telescopes up to 4\u2009m in diameter and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m\\simeq \\operatorname{22-24}$|</span> with the Subaru 8-m telescope (e.g. Cowperthwaite et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Soares-Santos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Arcavi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Yoshida et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Doctor et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Utsumi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). In general, these observations reached a sensitivity compatible with detecting a kilonova-like counterpart to the respective BH\u2013BH mergers and, as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>, their main aim was to implement and test a new type of observing campaign. We therefore adopted a nominal goal of reaching a spectral flux density limit with GMOS and MUSE corresponding to <em>i</em> \u2243 25, in order to push the sensitivity of EM follow-up observations into a new regime, independent of any lens magnification. In particular, we note that Doctor et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) observed the sky localization of GW170814 to a depth of <em>i</em> \u2243 23 with the Dark Energy Camera. Moreover, after taking account of lens magnification of (say) \u03bc \u2243 100, the depth to which we observe corresponds to a search for optical emission from BH\u2013BHs down to <em>i</em> \u2243 25\u00a0+\u00a02.5log\u2009(\u03bc)\u00a0= 30.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our observations are guided by the best localizations provided by the LVC at the time. Localizations are refined as improved analyses become available (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>), but since we expect a kilonova-like optical counterpart to fade rapidly, it is not possible to delay follow-up observations until final localizations are communicated. We identify the clusters for potential observations by comparing the celestial coordinates of 130 strong-lensing clusters selected by Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) with the LVC sky localization. We use the 2D sky localization to prioritize the most promising observing targets. Typically, we pick the strong-lensing cluster closest to the peak of the probability distribution as the most promising to observe.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our ToO observing programmes at the Gemini Observatory and European Southern Observatory (hereafter ESO) commenced in early 2017 August under programme IDs GN-2017A-DD-9, GS-2017A-DD-6, and 299.A-5028, respectively. These programmes allowed for up to 7\u2009epochs of imaging observations with the GMOS instruments on the Gemini-North and Gemini-South telescopes, and up to 3\u2009epochs of integral field spectroscopy with MUSE on VLT. The observations commence as soon as possible after receipt of the LVC alert via a rapid ToO, and were planned to extend over a period of one week following the alert via regular ToO observations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874593 id=\"132874593\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Identification of strong-lensing clusters in the GW170814 sky localization</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">GW170814 was detected by LIGO and Virgo on 2017 August 14 at 10:30:43 <span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span>, and first announced via GCN circular on 2017 August 14 at 12:28:42 <span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span> (LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>) with an initial false alarm rate of \u223c1 in 80\u2009000\u2009yr. The 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible region in the initial <span class=\"small-caps\">bayestar</span> (Singer\u00a0&amp; Price <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) sky localization spanned <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$97\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>, centred at celestial coordinates of (\u03b1, \u03b4)\u00a0= (02:44:00, \u221245:29:00). We identified one strong-lensing cluster, Abell 3084 (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), within the 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible region of the <span class=\"small-caps\">bayestar</span> map. Abell 3084 lies on the contour encircling a region within which the sky localization probability is <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.8, and which subtends <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$57.5\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|</span> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"132874595\" scrollto-destination=\"132874595\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a01.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=1ttrpVZEb5mQN8-S5zl-mOIC9qyBmFUtqhnxLVTtazWEmux~cFsgwdX8Dl~mELf~lDNdXeLGOkWOmWUfT6sGTU50FmVosxYZdGd1qtLQry2oG-eT3IGWDMGbuPTfAFKR3k4sTIerUfFJw95aeOBhdQAGxTGZYQ6E3BS06cG0V-cfACGWc-VMzejk2IJ9Fa0ko28ogxGW4x~tJiDJ3XqIB8ewNfORN2D-pfcFoEMG6xRImTFG1IszFM0OgmNJrIAjjGD-0crXji7fElDSxeoUQ-RJLek2Sp2bYVJrlhzmJcR~IiRD-7FZLvSYuZGn25g66m1EcWjywUO~NhCbgo54TA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left \u2013 Initial bayestar sky map for GW170814 from GCN\u200921474, showing the LIGO only contours (dotted), joint LIGO\u2013Virgo contours (solid), Abell 3084 (filled circle), and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open). Right \u2013 Initial LALInference sky map from GCN\u200921493 (solid) and most recent LALInference sky map from Abbott et\u00a0al. (2018b; dotted), both based on LIGO\u2013Virgo data, and the locations of both clusters. SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open circle) is closer to the peak of the sky localization than Abell\u20093084 (filled) in the revised maps. In both panels, the 90 (50)\u2009per\u2009cent credible region is shown as the thicker (thiner) contour, and galactic latitudes of \u00b120\u00b0 are indicated by the dashed lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874595/stz675fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874595\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=wpda09cLAw6MS4PafKwEhfqaPuyEpJZAzI4UsrpGE-PEeaZIRrWwJeyBJm7fXZ4fylIHWo9e1PfqbjSobE9W1LMxCz9SLiVyKqs3GXBnvZkQxD~dQu5j1HfC-I9y5Tsg4hKz8QyQNVsRwlDEelmkL9IF-7gGGkkoIHXm3f7Ey~buNHwrWpf5RlED3JzkKFVtAXCRUaXmRspserJ4FTDHtnla390NBoqfcmAj8bishO8FETK0BF1hYdtoREbSV1OxAt2tBtXKRB1I5jalXePWz4E55IsPsucLjCiXQKGn7bFWOF-O5TtrNXRzmtTM5nUtwmjidsjDBmDVgXr0dUfj7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874595&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">Left</span> \u2013 Initial <span class=\"small-caps\">bayestar</span> sky map for GW170814 from GCN\u200921474, showing the LIGO only contours (dotted), joint LIGO\u2013Virgo contours (solid), Abell 3084 (filled circle), and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open). <span class=\"small-caps\">Right</span> \u2013 Initial <span class=\"small-caps\">LALInference</span> sky map from GCN\u200921493 (solid) and most recent <span class=\"small-caps\">LALInference</span> sky map from Abbott et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>; dotted), both based on LIGO\u2013Virgo data, and the locations of both clusters. SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open circle) is closer to the peak of the sky localization than Abell\u20093084 (filled) in the revised maps. In both panels, the 90 (50)\u2009per\u2009cent credible region is shown as the thicker (thiner) contour, and galactic latitudes of \u00b120\u00b0 are indicated by the dashed lines.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a01.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=1ttrpVZEb5mQN8-S5zl-mOIC9qyBmFUtqhnxLVTtazWEmux~cFsgwdX8Dl~mELf~lDNdXeLGOkWOmWUfT6sGTU50FmVosxYZdGd1qtLQry2oG-eT3IGWDMGbuPTfAFKR3k4sTIerUfFJw95aeOBhdQAGxTGZYQ6E3BS06cG0V-cfACGWc-VMzejk2IJ9Fa0ko28ogxGW4x~tJiDJ3XqIB8ewNfORN2D-pfcFoEMG6xRImTFG1IszFM0OgmNJrIAjjGD-0crXji7fElDSxeoUQ-RJLek2Sp2bYVJrlhzmJcR~IiRD-7FZLvSYuZGn25g66m1EcWjywUO~NhCbgo54TA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left \u2013 Initial bayestar sky map for GW170814 from GCN\u200921474, showing the LIGO only contours (dotted), joint LIGO\u2013Virgo contours (solid), Abell 3084 (filled circle), and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open). Right \u2013 Initial LALInference sky map from GCN\u200921493 (solid) and most recent LALInference sky map from Abbott et\u00a0al. (2018b; dotted), both based on LIGO\u2013Virgo data, and the locations of both clusters. SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open circle) is closer to the peak of the sky localization than Abell\u20093084 (filled) in the revised maps. In both panels, the 90 (50)\u2009per\u2009cent credible region is shown as the thicker (thiner) contour, and galactic latitudes of \u00b120\u00b0 are indicated by the dashed lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874595/stz675fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874595\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=wpda09cLAw6MS4PafKwEhfqaPuyEpJZAzI4UsrpGE-PEeaZIRrWwJeyBJm7fXZ4fylIHWo9e1PfqbjSobE9W1LMxCz9SLiVyKqs3GXBnvZkQxD~dQu5j1HfC-I9y5Tsg4hKz8QyQNVsRwlDEelmkL9IF-7gGGkkoIHXm3f7Ey~buNHwrWpf5RlED3JzkKFVtAXCRUaXmRspserJ4FTDHtnla390NBoqfcmAj8bishO8FETK0BF1hYdtoREbSV1OxAt2tBtXKRB1I5jalXePWz4E55IsPsucLjCiXQKGn7bFWOF-O5TtrNXRzmtTM5nUtwmjidsjDBmDVgXr0dUfj7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874595&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">Left</span> \u2013 Initial <span class=\"small-caps\">bayestar</span> sky map for GW170814 from GCN\u200921474, showing the LIGO only contours (dotted), joint LIGO\u2013Virgo contours (solid), Abell 3084 (filled circle), and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open). <span class=\"small-caps\">Right</span> \u2013 Initial <span class=\"small-caps\">LALInference</span> sky map from GCN\u200921493 (solid) and most recent <span class=\"small-caps\">LALInference</span> sky map from Abbott et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>; dotted), both based on LIGO\u2013Virgo data, and the locations of both clusters. SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (open circle) is closer to the peak of the sky localization than Abell\u20093084 (filled) in the revised maps. In both panels, the 90 (50)\u2009per\u2009cent credible region is shown as the thicker (thiner) contour, and galactic latitudes of \u00b120\u00b0 are indicated by the dashed lines.</p></div></div> aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Abell 3084<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>SMACS\u2009J0304<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Cluster redshift\u00a0</td><td>0.22\u00a0</td><td>0.46\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Right ascension\u00a0</td><td>03:04:07\u00a0</td><td>03:04:21\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Declination\u00a0</td><td>\u221236:56:36\u00a0</td><td>\u221244:01:48\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>L<sub>X</sub></em>[0.1\u22122.4keV] (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$10^{44}\\mathrm{erg\\, s^{-1}}$|\u2060</span>)\u00a0</td><td>4.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6<sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>7.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Redshift of multiple-image system\u00a0</td><td>0.764<sup><em>c</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>1.963<sup><em>d</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> B\u00f6hringer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>)</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Repp\u00a0&amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> May (2013)</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf4\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup> Christensen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/132874596\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As the LVC analyses were refined, the localization region evolved (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). On 2017 August 16 at 07:02:19 <span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span>, the sky localization was updated based on the results of <span class=\"small-caps\">LALInference</span> (Veitch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), with a revised peak close to celestial coordinates of (\u03b1, \u03b4)\u00a0= (03:06:00, \u221244:36:00) and a 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible region spanning <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$190\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|</span> (LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>). We identified two strong-lensing clusters within the 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible region of the <span class=\"small-caps\">LALInference</span> map. Abell 3084 lay on the contour encircling <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.873\u2009per\u2009cent of the localization probability density, corresponding to a region subtending <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$154.4\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|</span> \u2013 i.e. this cluster is further from the peak of the probability distribution following the update. SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) was closer to the peak of the probability distribution, on the contour that encloses <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.05 of the sky localization probability and subtends <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.1\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">When GW170814 was first announced outside the LVC and EM follow-up partners in 2017 October (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017b</a>), the best sky localization peaked close to (\u03b1, \u03b4)\u00a0= (03:10:00, \u221244:51:00), with a 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible region spanning <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$60\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>, and a luminosity distance of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\rm L}=540^{+130}_{-210}\\, \\mathrm{Mpc}$|\u2060</span>. With this, Abell 3084 lay on the <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.994 contour that subtends <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$170.4\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>, and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 lay on the <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.57 contour that subtends <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16.1\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>. Subsequently, the LIGO\u2013Virgo data were recalibrated and cleaned for the O2 Catalogue results (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). Analysis of these improved data gave a localization peaking close to (\u03b1, \u03b4)\u00a0= (03:09:00, \u221244:36:00) with a 90\u2009per\u2009cent credible region spanning <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$90\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>, and a luminosity distance of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\rm L}=580^{+160}_{-210}\\, \\mathrm{Mpc}$|\u2060</span>. With this, Abell 3084 lay on the <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.96 contour that subtends <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$170.2\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>, and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 lay on the <em>p</em>\u00a0= 0.30 contour that subtends <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.7\\, {\\rm deg}^2$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874599 id=\"132874599\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Abell 3084 and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Abell 3084 and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 are X-ray luminous galaxy clusters at intermediate redshift (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Virial mass estimates of both clusters are not published to date, however, their X-ray luminosities are consistent with them both having a mass of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> \u2243 10<sup>15</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Both are spectroscopically confirmed strong lenses, each with one multiple-image system confirmed to date. Detailed models of the mass distribution in the cluster cores (May 2013; Christensen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) are vital to interpreting the sensitivity of our observations and any flux that we detect from a candidate EM counterpart. The models are most accurate for sources at redshifts similar to the known multiple-image system redshifts; we therefore concentrate on these redshifts when considering the efficiency of our search for candidate EM counterparts in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) snapshot observations with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) are available for both clusters, through the F606W filter (PID:10881 and 12166). We use these data to calibrate our GMOS and MUSE observations (Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5</a>\u00a0and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-6\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.6</a>) and in our difference image analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874601 id=\"132874601\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Gemini and VLT observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We observed Abell 3084 with GMOS on Gemini-S on five occasions, commencing 20\u2009h after the first LVC alert pertaining to GW170814, on 2017 August 15 <span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span>. This was the first Chilean night following the detection of GW170814. The GMOS observations of Abell 3084 continued after the revised sky map became available, in order to obtain a comprehensive data set on one cluster. We also observed SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401 with GMOS on Gemini-S on two occasions \u2013 August 18 and 21. The overall aim was to observe for \u223c45\u2009min on each night, with the exposure times and the number of exposures adjusted to suit the Moon phase and overhead conditions. The individual exposures were offset from each other randomly within a square region of full width <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$30\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>. Observations were performed in the <em>i</em>-band in order to minimize the impact of the Moon on the sensitivity of the observations, and to probe rest-frame <em>V</em>-band emission from putative lensed GWs at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z\\, \\gtrsim \\, 0.5$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We triggered a rapid ToO on VLT with MUSE within 3\u2009h after LVC announced the detection of GW170814. This observation was executed at the telescope on 2017 August 17 <span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span>, and repeated on 2017 August 20 <span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span>. The delay between our trigger and the first MUSE observation was due to a combination of visitor mode time and engineering time on the intervening nights. Each observation comprised three exposures of duration <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$980\\, {\\rm s}$|</span> and spanned the wavelength range <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$475\\, {\\rm nm}\\,\\,\\lt\\,\\, \\lambda\\,\\, \\lt\\,\\, 930\\, {\\rm nm}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All of the GMOS and MUSE data were obtained at high elevation and with excellent seeing of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.5\\, {\\rm arcsec}\\le {\\rm FWHM}\\le 1\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>. Details of the GMOS and MUSE observations are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and the reduction of GMOS and MUSE data is described in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5</a>\u00a0and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-6\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.6</a>, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"132874605\" scrollto-destination=\"132874605\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table\u00a02.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up observations of strong-lensing clusters within sky localization of GW170814.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Visit<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Start of observation (<span class=\"small-caps\">utc</span>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Airmass<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Integration<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing<sup><em>b</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Sensitivity<sup><em>c</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>time (ks)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td colspan=\"6\"><span class=\"small-caps\">GMOS Observations of Abell 3084</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2017 August 15, 3084</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td>2017 August 17, 08:02:13\u00a0</td><td>1.10\u00a0</td><td>2.9\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td><td>25.8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2\u00a0</td><td>2017 August 19, 07:46:50\u00a0</td><td>1.12\u00a0</td><td>2.9\u00a0</td><td>0.82\u00a0</td><td>25.9\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf5\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> The airmass at the mid-point of the observation.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Mean full width at half-maximum of point sources in the reduced data, with a typical error on the mean of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }0.02\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf7\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> 5\u03c3 point source sensitivity within a photometric aperture of diameter <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2\\, {\\rm arcsec}$|\u2060</span>, estimated from the magnitude at which the median photometric uncertainty is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.2\\, {\\rm magnitudes}$|\u2060</span>. The sensitivity of the MUSE observations is stated in the F606W-band.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/132874605\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874606 id=\"132874606\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5>2.5 GMOS data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Individual GMOS exposures were de-biased, dark-subtracted, flat-fielded, and sky-subtracted in the standard manner using the <span class=\"small-caps\">gemini</span> package in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span>, to produce both a single science frame comprising the mosaiced individual chips, and a bad-pixel map, for each exposure. The bad-pixel maps were applied to the science frames and the individual masked science frames were then combined into a single stacked frame per visit using the <span class=\"small-caps\">imcombine</span> task in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span>. The full width at half-maximum of point sources in the reduced frames is consistently subarcsecond (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The reduced and stacked frames were aligned with the first visit for that target to a typical root-mean-square residual accuracy of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.03\\, {\\rm pixels}$|</span> using the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> tasks <span class=\"small-caps\">geomap</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">geotran</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We searched the available USNO and GSC catalogues for sources of well calibrated <em>i</em>-band magnitude within the field of view of our GMOS data. The size and depth of the GMOS imaging even in short exposures meant that there was no overlap between unsaturated bright stars as seen by Gemini and faint stars measured in all-sky surveys. We therefore calibrated the GMOS frames by measuring the (<em>V</em><sub>606</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em>) colours of sources detected in both the archival <em>HST</em>/ACS data and our GMOS data, and selecting the photometric zero-point that yields the correct colours for massive early-type galaxies in Abell 3084 and SMACS\u2009J0304.3\u00a0\u2212 4401, respectively. These colours were computed using the <span class=\"small-caps\">ezgal</span> code,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> using a single stellar population that formed at high redshift and evolved passively to the relevant cluster redshifts based on the Bruzual\u00a0&amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) population-synthesis code. The predicted colours are insensitive to the fine details of how we choose the formation redshift and the metallicity. We show an example (<em>V</em><sub>606</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em>)/<em>i</em> colour-magnitude diagram for one of the observations of Abell 3084 in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"132874609\" scrollto-destination=\"132874609\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=Dj3dd3E1Hf5pw8zV-8FBacWeRjcM833rFByq0Ve73GVLPFIdSD7Feoc4rLEaZGC~RcUFvYznAChrcN3eZb4OkSqW522d~1OKj~CqwHiNYyHtn1WxGLBBTelABNePVD4gNimupI5k2SrfI4SCU0uL007TZV~gbgnxmZe5NWOv0GjzUg0wkfjk3R1tGwpVt9KKqcQ96lsWkQ6N6JHYSfjtiec6S9vyih1JcyFV6cZi-zX5m3Hu9TZRUufAqpm9P16LiVOcLEjF71tiJesS2lRXoZv9iU~J1w71HuA3BtSwS-26HbKSanRIYjDF1yRVmjdGRAC4J~PNzGuuqwFOCnPshw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example colour\u2013magnitude diagram for Abell 3084 based on our GMOS and archival HST/ACS data. The horizontal dashed line shows the predicted colour of a single stellar population that formed at high redshift and evolved passively to the cluster redshift (z\u00a0= 0.22). The photometric zero-point of the GMOS frame was chosen to match the colour of the sequence of massive (i &lt; 20) cluster early-type galaxies to this prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874609/stz675fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874609\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=GPiqb0oDkzUYok6WdY7mKdPhrzU9XEIxR0LV2Ppm-WqQfGopelBTUjlegFNCjcWWtrpc-Zvrh~12RcKb1rsMjzR7j1RdrJLcSQ6Oc0Ds3DaD85cI9qn0gd0-4zQnIxe-~kJSVPkcVov7AaVkcC3VlT2zQAcITdEP5Pyg9FqNK9P49AAZryBaMHbvMWXRd7IXaaLFz1dgMgGwPFFf8F8cZ17upb~SOHsa4y-vTrEY3h-HM7-LvkDVgyqo-ZrGhuKoOdGEXk~7EHq-Y3caAIKQkzcTgOn-PaUpxjxzM-jN9~H4P5s70MUm8n5QP1i9wYHYyEvi0dgBqqggRPkjOhPsZQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874609&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example colour\u2013magnitude diagram for Abell 3084 based on our GMOS and archival <em>HST</em>/ACS data. The horizontal dashed line shows the predicted colour of a single stellar population that formed at high redshift and evolved passively to the cluster redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.22). The photometric zero-point of the GMOS frame was chosen to match the colour of the sequence of massive (<em>i</em> &lt; 20) cluster early-type galaxies to this prediction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a02.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=Dj3dd3E1Hf5pw8zV-8FBacWeRjcM833rFByq0Ve73GVLPFIdSD7Feoc4rLEaZGC~RcUFvYznAChrcN3eZb4OkSqW522d~1OKj~CqwHiNYyHtn1WxGLBBTelABNePVD4gNimupI5k2SrfI4SCU0uL007TZV~gbgnxmZe5NWOv0GjzUg0wkfjk3R1tGwpVt9KKqcQ96lsWkQ6N6JHYSfjtiec6S9vyih1JcyFV6cZi-zX5m3Hu9TZRUufAqpm9P16LiVOcLEjF71tiJesS2lRXoZv9iU~J1w71HuA3BtSwS-26HbKSanRIYjDF1yRVmjdGRAC4J~PNzGuuqwFOCnPshw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example colour\u2013magnitude diagram for Abell 3084 based on our GMOS and archival HST/ACS data. The horizontal dashed line shows the predicted colour of a single stellar population that formed at high redshift and evolved passively to the cluster redshift (z\u00a0= 0.22). The photometric zero-point of the GMOS frame was chosen to match the colour of the sequence of massive (i &lt; 20) cluster early-type galaxies to this prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/132874609/stz675fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"132874609\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/stz675fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&Signature=GPiqb0oDkzUYok6WdY7mKdPhrzU9XEIxR0LV2Ppm-WqQfGopelBTUjlegFNCjcWWtrpc-Zvrh~12RcKb1rsMjzR7j1RdrJLcSQ6Oc0Ds3DaD85cI9qn0gd0-4zQnIxe-~kJSVPkcVov7AaVkcC3VlT2zQAcITdEP5Pyg9FqNK9P49AAZryBaMHbvMWXRd7IXaaLFz1dgMgGwPFFf8F8cZ17upb~SOHsa4y-vTrEY3h-HM7-LvkDVgyqo-ZrGhuKoOdGEXk~7EHq-Y3caAIKQkzcTgOn-PaUpxjxzM-jN9~H4P5s70MUm8n5QP1i9wYHYyEvi0dgBqqggRPkjOhPsZQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=132874609&ar=5372447&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz675fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example colour\u2013magnitude diagram for Abell 3084 based on our GMOS and archival <em>HST</em>/ACS data. The horizontal dashed line shows the predicted colour of a single stellar population that formed at high redshift and evolved passively to the cluster redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.22). The photometric zero-point of the GMOS frame was chosen to match the colour of the sequence of massive (<em>i</em> &lt; 20) cluster early-type galaxies to this prediction.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874610 id=\"132874610\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-6>2.6 MUSE data reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The MUSE observations were reduced using version 2.0 of the data reduction software (Weilbacher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The process includes basic calibration (bias removal, flat-fielding, wavelength, and geometrical calibration) and the production of datacubes for each exposure following sky subtraction, flux calibration, and telluric correction. These datacubes were matched in astrometry to the relevant <em>HST</em> observation discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>. In all cases, only a constant offset in right ascension and declination was applied, as no significant rotation was found. The measured offsets and rotation were applied back to the original list of pixels (the pixel table), so that the datacubes can be produced in a single interpolation step to limit the effect on the noise properties. Each exposure's datacube was treated for sky subtraction residuals using the PCA method implemented in the <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> v2.0 software (Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We then combined all zapped exposures taken during each of the two observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We assessed the image quality of the MUSE observations by performing a Moffat spatial fit of the bright unsaturated stars in each exposure. The seeing was stable in each night with average values provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We also estimated the cloud extinction to be just a few per\u2009cent and thus negligible, based on a comparison between MUSE pseudo-F606W frames (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>) and relevant <em>HST</em> frames.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=132874613 id=\"132874613\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 ANALYSIS AND RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=132874614 id=\"132874614\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Difference images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We normalized each reduced and stacked GMOS frame to an exposure time of 1\u2009s, and then matched the image quality between visits using the <span class=\"small-caps\">psfmatch</span> task in <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span>. The point spread function (PSF) model was empirical and based on 10 isolated, unsaturated, high signal-to-noise ratio stars in the vicinity of the strong-lensing region of each frame. These matched frames were then subtracted from each other in pairs to produce difference images, examples of which are shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>\u00a0and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"132874616\" scrollto-destination=\"132874616\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure\u00a03.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/485/4/10.1093_mnras_stz675/1/m_stz675fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465129&amp;Signature=olq~i9KZ4fHmZVC8W2yPrtKez-tEQPKywpLWPJqkUT-oG9KBG2EO8F0rQRe7Hsy6qm19UuFMe~~U2JSBb91GYUl8iPKdTU7~HTycd2om-QCIaXacof2Ddu3Dzq~d~1r2W04Pd9G8gm2LWlQ7Q15USN2bRRxlir9ecTLMK-gbR64ijMQkvpuVs3Yy40wkmaMRHmO27CgpJqAj44CmHilAQUrhoSGJANmAMkmWrgrzV0P5NEWuOzYvGmvZfj6wFZlAwodhs4g8ayilR2p3f7AJcKGPhIR3rmtfDxpBVXmzg4z3sJRE7qfq7bOVnqxvabd-IEv19YI7~R7ln4-6C1awIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Central region of Abell 3084, with the BCG at the origin in each panel.
